  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="49%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:49.0%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Indicate
by check mark whether the registrant is a shell company (as defined in Rule&nbsp;12b-2
of the Act).&#160; Yes </font><font size="2" face="Wingdings" style="font-size:10.0pt;">o</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> No </font><font size="2" face="Wingdings" style="font-size:10.0pt;">x</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
aggregate market value of voting stock held by non-affiliates of the
registrant, computed using the closing sale price of common stock of $62.66 on September&nbsp;30,
2007 was $546,583,000.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">8,768,257
shares of registrant&#146;s common stock were outstanding on May&nbsp;28, 2008.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">DOCUMENTS INCORPORATED BY REFERENCE</font></b></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;text-indent:.2in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">The
registrant intends to file a definitive Proxy Statement pursuant to Regulation
14A within 120 days of the end of the fiscal year ended March&nbsp;31, 2008.
Portions of such Proxy Statement are incorporated by reference in Part&nbsp;III.</font></b></p>

<div style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 6.0pt;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;">

<p align="center" style="border:none;color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;padding:0in;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

</div>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="6%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:6.64%;">
  <p align="right" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">24</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="13%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:13.34%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="80%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:80.02%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="6%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:6.64%;">
  <p align="right" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="13%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:13.34%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="80%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:80.02%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;"><a href="#Partiii_202330">PART&nbsp;III</a></font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="6%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:6.64%;">
  <p align="right" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="13%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:13.34%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="80%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:80.02%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="6%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:6.64%;">

  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="13%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:13.34%;">

  </td>
  <td width="80%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:80.02%;">

  Executive Officers and Corporate Governance</a></font></p>

 </tr>

  Matters </a></font></p>

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='2',FILE='C:\JMS\C900154\08-15969-1\task2985867\15969-1-ba-01.htm',USER='c900154',CD='Jun 13 09:44 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">CAUTIONARY STATEMENT</font></b></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">This Annual Report and
the documents incorporated by reference contain forward-looking
statements.&#160; For this purpose, any
statements contained herein that are not statements of historical fact may be
deemed to be forward-looking statements.&#160;
Without limiting the foregoing, the words &#147;believes&#148;, &#147;anticipates&#148;, &#147;plans&#148;,
&#147;expects&#148;, &#147;should&#148; and similar expressions are intended to identify
forward-looking statements.&#160; The factors
discussed under &#147;Item 1A. Risk Factors&#148;, among others, could cause actual
results to differ materially from those indicated by forward-looking statements
made herein and presented elsewhere by management from time to time.&#160; We expressly disclaim any obligation to
update or alter our forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information,
future events or otherwise, except as required by law.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">All references in this
Annual report to &#147;AS&amp;E&#148;, the &#147;Company&#148;, &#147;we&#148;, &#147;our&#148; and &#147;us&#148; means American
Science and Engineering,&nbsp;Inc. and its subsidiary.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">PART&nbsp;I</font></b><a name="Parti_081952"></a></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">ITEM 1.
BUSINESS</font></b><a name="Item1_Business_081956"></a></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">American Science and
Engineering,&nbsp;Inc., a Massachusetts corporation formed in 1958, develops,
manufactures, markets, and sells X-ray inspection and other inspection
solutions for homeland security and other targeted markets.&#160; AS&amp;E<i><sup><font style="font-style:italic;position:relative;top:-3.0pt;">&#174;</font></sup></i>&#160;provides maintenance, warranty, research,
engineering, and training services related to these solutions.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company manufactures
sophisticated X-ray inspection products that can be used to inspect parcels,
baggage, vehicles, pallets, cargo containers, and people.&#160; The Company sells its products in the United
States and throughout the world to a variety of customers, including:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Authorities responsible for port and border security</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Aviation security agencies</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Military organizations; and</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">High threat commercial and government facilities</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">AS&amp;E&#146;s products are used by these customers to
help combat terrorism, trade fraud, drug trafficking, weapons smuggling, and
illegal immigration.&#160; Our products are
also used for military force protection and general facility security.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Beginning with the terrorist
attacks on September&nbsp;11, 2001, and continuing with the proliferation of
global terrorism, homeland security and force protection concerns have become
of paramount importance in the United States and around the world. The Company
believes that homeland defense, force protection and military security
initiatives will continue to provide new revenue opportunities, with additional
growth in the seaports and borders, federal and military facilities, and
corporate security markets.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s objective
is to distinguish itself from its competitors by offering innovative products
which provide superior threat detection. To achieve this, AS&amp;E incorporates
a variety of X-ray imaging and image processing technologies into its products.&#160; A number of the Company&#146;s products use our
patented Z Backscatter&#153; technology.&#160; Z
Backscatter is a unique X-ray imaging technique that has distinct advantages
for the detection of organic or low atomic number (Z)&nbsp;materials such as
plastic explosives, composite weapons, and illegal drugs even when concealed by
complex backgrounds.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Technology</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s X-ray
imaging products utilize several technologies including traditional
transmission X-ray technology, our proprietary Z Backscatter technology, Shaped
Energy technology and Radioactive Threat Detection (RTD).</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">X-ray imaging devices
contain these basic subsystems: X-ray sources, detectors, and software.&#160; The source generates an X-ray beam that is
directed at the object to be scanned (baggage, container, etc.).&#160; When the source X-rays encounter the object,
they are either absorbed by the object, pass directly through the object, or
scatter off of the object.&#160; Dense (high
atomic number) materials tend to absorb X-rays.&#160;
Materials that are less dense (low atomic number) tend to scatter
X-rays.&#160; The detectors record the
intensity of the transmitted or scattered X-rays.&#160; Software is then used to interpret the
signals from the detectors and to construct and display X-ray images.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Transmission
X-ray Technology:</font></i></b><i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">&#160; </font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Transmission images are created from X-rays that pass
through the object that is being examined.&#160;
Medical X-ray images are a type of transmission X-ray.&#160; In transmission imaging, the detector
measures the relative intensity of the X-rays that pass directly through the
object.&#160; The degree to which X-rays are
transmitted through an object is dependant upon the size of the X-ray source
and the composition and quantity of the material in the path of the X-ray
beam.&#160; Low energy sources are used to
scan smaller objects such as parcels and baggage, and high energy sources are
used for scanning large </font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">3</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='3',FILE='C:\JMS\C900154\08-15969-1\task2985867\15969-1-ba-01.htm',USER='c900154',CD='Jun 13 09:44 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">items such as trucks and cargo containers.&#160; Transmission X-ray images are useful for
seeing &#147;through&#148; the object of interest.&#160;
A transmission image, however, represents an aggregate of all objects in
the path on the beam and can therefore be difficult to interpret.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Z
Backscatter Technology:</font></i></b><i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">&#160; </font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Most of the Company&#146;s X-ray systems
utilize AS&amp;E&#146;s patented Z Backscatter technology.&#160; The term &#147;Backscatter&#148; refers to those X-rays
that <i>scatter</i> off of the object
under examination <i>back</i> toward the
X-ray source.&#160; Z Backscatter detectors
capture these scattered X-rays which are then used to create highly readable,
photo-like images.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Many threat items are organic
in nature and have low atomic numbers.&#160;
Such items include drugs, explosives, composite weapons, and
stowaways.&#160; These items tend to scatter
X-rays much more so than inorganic materials like steel and other metals.&#160; As a result, these organic threat items tend
to stand out as bright, visible objects when scanned by a Z Backscatter imaging
system.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Z Backscatter images
complement transmission images and several of the Company&#146;s products employ
both technologies.&#160; The combination of
backscatter and transmission images gives security officials more information
about the contents of the baggage or container by differentiating dense
materials, such as metals, from low-Z materials such as explosives.&#160; In addition, the two images enable an
inspector to perform a quicker and more thorough examination of the object in
question.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Other Technologies:</font></i></b><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Two other technologies employed by AS&amp;E are Shaped
Energy and Radioactive Threat Detection (RTD).&#160;
Shaped Energy technology is a specialized form of high energy transmission
X-ray which is used in AS&amp;E&#146;s OmniView product line. Radioactive Threat
Detection (RTD) is a technology which is used to find radioactive materials in
vehicles.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Products
and Systems</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s products
and services can be grouped into six different areas including CargoSearch&#153;
Inspection Systems, Z Backscatter Systems, ParcelSearch&#153; Inspection Systems,
Personnel Inspection, Contract Research and Development, and Service and
Support.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">CargoSearch&#153;
Inspection Systems:</font></i></b><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> The CargoSearch family of systems includes non-intrusive inspection
products which are primarily used for the screening of trucks, cars, cargo
containers, pallets, and air cargo at locations including border crossings,
seaports, military bases, railroad centers, airports, and cargo and
transportation hubs. The CargoSearch systems are designed to combat trade
fraud, drug trafficking, weapons smuggling, and terrorism. The CargoSearch
family includes:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .2in;text-indent:.2in;"><i><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">OmniView&#153; Gantry System</font></u></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">:&#160; a multi-view,
relocatable high-energy cargo and vehicle inspection system.&#160; This system combines 6 MeV high-energy
transmission imaging and three Z Backscatter X-ray views for left, right and
top-side imaging of cargo.&#160; OmniView
provides side and top-down views of the cargo in a relocatable configuration.
OmniView utilizes AS&amp;E&#146;s patented Shaped Energy&#153; technology to penetrate
densely loaded cargo containers. Shaped Energy &#147;shapes&#148; the high energy
spectrum to filter out non-essential radiation, making the system safe for
operators and staff.&#160; High energy 6.0 MeV
transmission X-rays can penetrate 14 inches (35 cm) of steel or 8.5 feet (260
cm) of oil, yet doesn&#146;t require heavy shielding, an exterior building, or
standoff zones.&#160;&#160; The Z Backscatter
images are ideal for the detection of organic or &#147;low Z&#148; materials including
explosives, drugs, alcohol, and tobacco that transmission X-rays alone can
miss. The System&#146;s multiple Z Backscatter views of the cargo improve detection
while facilitating interpretation of the X-ray image.&#160; The OmniView Gantry System&#146;s scanning
platform operates by moving on rails past stationary vehicles and cargo.&#160; The system is bi-directional allowing for a
throughput of approximately 25 trucks per hour.&#160;
OmniView Gantry is ideal for ports, borders, and high-threat military
facilities.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 13.5pt;text-indent:13.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .2in;text-indent:.2in;"><i><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Z Portal</font></u></i><u><sup><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#174;</font></sup></u><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">:&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">a multi-view, high throughput, drive-through
inspection system capable of scanning cars, vans, trucks, and their cargoes for
threats and contraband.&#160; The relocatable
screening system can be configured with one, two or three Z Backscatter X-ray
detectors, allowing for left, right and/or top-side imaging of the vehicle
under examination.&#160; The images produced
by the Z Portal are ideal for the detection of organic materials including
explosives, drugs, alcohol, tobacco, and stowaways.&#160; The Z Portal is well-suited for scanning
vehicles at border crossings, high threat facilities, and other vehicle entry
checkpoints.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 13.5pt;text-indent:13.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .2in;text-indent:.2in;"><i><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">PalletSearch&#153;</font></u></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">:&#160; a conveyorized X-ray
inspection system designed to perform non-intrusive inspection of mixed cargo
shipped on large pallets or in air cargo containers.&#160; The system is especially useful for
inspecting large, irregularly shaped containers and cargo.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 13.5pt;text-indent:13.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Z Backscatter
Systems:</font></i></b><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#160; Z Backscatter Systems include imaging systems
that use Z Backscatter imaging only.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .2in;text-indent:.2in;"><i><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Z Backscatter Van&#153; (ZBV</font></u></i><u><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">)</font></u><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">: a mobile X-ray screening system built
into a commercially available chassis.&#160;
It utilizes Z Backscatter X-ray technology to produce photo-like images
of the contents of a vehicle or cargo container, highlighting organic materials
such as plastic explosives or other anomalies. With one-sided, backscatter-only
imaging, security officials can use </font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">4</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='4',FILE='C:\JMS\C900154\08-15969-1\task2985867\15969-1-ba-01.htm',USER='c900154',CD='Jun 13 09:44 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 13.5pt;text-indent:-13.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ZBV for screening
vehicles, sea containers, and other cargo for terrorist threats, trade fraud,
and contraband, simply by driving past the objects.&#160;&#160; The ZBV can be equipped with Radioactive
Threat Detection (RTD) capability.&#160; With
RTD, the ZBV can produce Z Backscatter images for general screening while
simultaneously scanning the object for the presence of radioactive
material.&#160; The ZBV is available in
several versions, including a militarized trailer configuration (ZBV Mil
Trailer) that is designed for use by the U.S. military.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 13.5pt;text-indent:-13.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">ParcelSearch</font></i></b><b><i><font size="1" style="font-size:7.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;position:relative;top:-3.0pt;">&#153;</font></i></b><b><i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">&#160;Inspection Systems:</font></i></b><i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">  </font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#160;ParcelSearch
systems are designed for the non-intrusive X-ray scanning of parcels, baggage,
and mail. These systems are primarily located in government facilities,
airports, commercial office buildings, high-security federal facilities and
convention centers. ParcelSearch systems include:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .2in;text-indent:.2in;"><i><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Gemini</font></u></i><i><u><sup><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">&#153;</font></sup></u></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">:&#160;
Gemini is a parcel and baggage inspection system which combines AS&amp;E&#146;s
Z Backscatter technology with Dual-energy transmission X-ray to provide
enhanced detection for a wide range of threats.&#160;
Dual-energy transmission is best suited for the detection of threats
such as guns and knives, and for identifying wires and other components of
improvised explosive devises (&#147;IEDs&#148;). It also provides some organic and
metallic discrimination in uncluttered environments.&#160; Z Backscatter imaging provides enhanced
detection of organic materials such as explosives and narcotics, which may be
missed by transmission-only systems in cluttered baggage.&#160; In addition, the complementary photo-like Z
Backscatter image makes it easier for security officers to interpret images,
thus reducing analysis time and minimizing operator fatigue.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 13.5pt;text-indent:22.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .2in;text-indent:.2in;"><i><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Model 101VAN&#153;</font></u></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">:</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> a self-contained conveyor-based parcel inspection
system housed in a standard van; designed and built to the rigorous specifications
of U.S. Customs and Border Protection.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 13.5pt;text-indent:22.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .2in;text-indent:.2in;"><i><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Models 101Z&#153;</font></u></i><i><u><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">, 101ZZ&#153;, and 101XL&#153;</font></u></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">:<i>  </i>conveyor-based
systems allowing rapid inspection of high volumes of luggage and other
packages.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 13.5pt;text-indent:22.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Personnel
Screening:</font></i></b><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#160; Personnel screening is a crucial part of any
threat detection effort.&#160; Today, threats
can take the smallest of forms and are often easily hidden on a person.&#160; With the advent of suicide bombings,
personnel screening has taken on an even more important role.&#160; Personnel screening is also important in the effort
to intercept prohibited substances, such as drugs and alcohol.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .2in;text-indent:.2in;"><i><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">SmartCheck&#153;</font></u></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">:&#160; a
personnel screening system for the effective screening for contraband and
threats hidden under a person&#146;s clothing.&#160;
SmartCheck simultaneously detects both metallic and non-metallic
objects, such as guns and knives, plastic explosives, liquid explosives,
composite weapons, drugs and other hidden threats and contraband.&#160; Its Z Backscatter image gives the operator an
easy-to-read display of where the threat or contraband is hidden, thus
eliminating the need for intrusive and time-consuming pat-downs and strip
searches.&#160; SmartCheck employs proprietary
advanced image processing algorithms to enhance privacy, while maintaining a
high level of threat detection.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 13.5pt;text-indent:-13.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Contract Research&nbsp;&amp; Development</font></i></b><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">:&#160;
AS&amp;E engages in a variety of contract research and development (CRAD)
programs, mostly for agencies of the U.S. government.&#160; AS&amp;E pursues CRAD opportunities which it
believes provide avenues for advancing our core technologies or developing
product offerings for strategic customers or markets.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Service and
Support:</font></i></b><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#160;&#160; AS&amp;E&#146;s highly skilled Field Service
Engineers (FSEs) provide support services worldwide. Each FSE has a technical
degree in Electrical and/or Mechanical Engineering (or equivalent experience),
and is trained in the operation and repair of electronics, hydraulics,
pneumatics, mechanics, electrical systems, and computers. FSEs are available 7
days a week, 24 hours a day, and are located at AS&amp;E offices in Asia,
Central America, Europe, the Middle East, and North America.&#160;&#160; In addition, Technical Support is provided
at the Company&#146;s headquarters in Billerica, Massachusetts. AS&amp;E provides
comprehensive, cost-effective spare parts solutions customized for each
system.&#160; The Company maintains an
inventory of field-replaceable components in order to meet customer needs for
spare parts.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">AS&amp;E provides
comprehensive technical training on all X-ray inspection systems. Our
instructors specialize in current threat detection techniques and employ both
classroom theory and hands-on training to help clients become expert users of
AS&amp;E equipment. Our technical training informs customers about detection
technologies and best practices through demonstrations and field activities
that simulate real-life threat and contraband encounters.&#160; Technical training is included with each system
sale and additional training for image analysis, service and maintenance
training, and other customized training courses are provided aftermarket to
interested customers.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Intellectual
Property</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company relies on a
combination of patent, copyright, trademark, contract and trade secret laws to
establish and protect its proprietary rights in its technology. The Company has
patents either issued and/or pending in the United States, Germany, Japan, the
United Kingdom, China, Austria, France, Ireland, Italy, Switzerland, Australia,
Canada, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Greece, Italy, Netherlands, Portugal, Spain,
Sweden, Turkey, Hong Kong, India, Israel, The Republic of Korea, New Zealand,
Mexico, </font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">5</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='5',FILE='C:\JMS\C900154\08-15969-1\task2985867\15969-1-ba-01.htm',USER='c900154',CD='Jun 13 09:44 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Norway, The Russian Federation, Ukraine, Singapore,
United Arab Emirates, Malaysia, Thailand and Egypt, and under the Gulf
Cooperation Council and the Patent Cooperation Treaty.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In general, the Company
pursues a policy of obtaining patent protection both in the United States and
in selected foreign countries for subject matter we consider patentable and
important to our business strategy. The Company has 63 unexpired patents issued
by, and 59 patent applications pending with, the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office,
as well as with the respective patent offices of the foreign countries noted
above. Over half of our issued patents have been issued in the last five years.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Generally, patents issued
in the United States are effective for the longer of 17 years from the date of
issue or 20 years from the earliest effective filing date of the corresponding
patent application if filed prior to June&nbsp;8, 1995. The duration of foreign
patents varies in accordance with applicable local law. While the duration of
our patents varies, we believe that the duration of our patents is adequate
relative to the expected lives of our products.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company believes that
its patents, proprietary technology, know-how, and trademarks provide
substantial protection for the Company&#146;s competitive position and the Company
intends to aggressively protect its intellectual property assets, by litigation
or other means, as appropriate. Nevertheless, there can be no assurances that
the steps taken by the Company in this regard will be adequate to prevent
misappropriation or infringement of its technology or that the Company&#146;s
competitors will not independently develop technologies that are substantially
equivalent or superior to the Company&#146;s technology. Effective protection of
intellectual property rights may be limited or unavailable in certain foreign
countries. See &#147;Item 3. Legal Proceedings&#148; below.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Sales and
Marketing</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s X-ray
products are marketed to corporate and governmental organizations through a
sales force that contacts potential customers and responds to public tenders
and other expressions of interest. This sales force includes Company personnel
based in the United States and abroad, as well as independent representatives
under contracts to sell in foreign countries.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Customers</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has a
customer base consisting of government and commercial clients from both the
United States and abroad. Domestically, the Company&#146;s primary client base is
comprised of agencies of the U.S. Government. Approximately 55%, 70%, and 77%
of the Company&#146;s total sales in fiscal 2008, 2007, and 2006, respectively, were
derived from either (i)&nbsp;contracting directly with the U.S. Government, or (ii)&nbsp;contracting
with contractors working directly with the U.S. Government. Certain of the
Company&#146;s contracts with the U.S. Government provide the U.S. Government with
the standard unilateral right to terminate these contracts for convenience. To
date, the Company has not experienced any material losses as a result of this
contractual provision. The Company is heavily dependent upon sales to agencies
of the U.S. Government and reductions or delays in procurement of the Company&#146;s
systems and services by these agencies may have a material adverse effect on
the Company.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">International sales,
primarily to foreign governments, accounted for approximately 36%, 27%, and 14%
of the Company&#146;s total sales in fiscal 2008, 2007, and 2006 respectively, and
continue to be a high priority for the Company as part of its long-term growth
strategy. International sales entail longer sales cycles and project financing
requirements; however the Company continues to focus on these sales as a means
of broadening its customer base and reducing its dependency on sales to the
U.S. Government. The Company manages its overseas risk in a number of ways,
including actively increasing the number of opportunities it is pursuing at any
one time, working with international funding sources to help customers finance
and secure funding of these projects, and obtaining downpayments and letters of
credit to secure its international receivables. The majority of international
contracts are bid in U.S. dollars. For those contracts that are bid in other
currencies, the Company considers the need to engage in hedging contracts to
control foreign exchange risk. There were no hedging activities in fiscal 2008,
2007, or 2006.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In fiscal 2008,
the Company had sales to two major customers, both agencies of the U.S.
Government, which accounted for 12% and 10% of total sales.&#160; In fiscal 2007, the Company had sales to two
major customers, both agencies of the U.S. Government, which accounted for 31%
and 15% of total sales.&#160; In fiscal 2006,
these same customers accounted for 26% and 30% of total sales.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Competition</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has many
competitors in the homeland security X-ray detection market, including several
large and well-established manufacturers of security equipment with financial
and other resources greater than those of the Company. Certain X-ray security
system customers select such systems based largely on price. Other customers,
including some agencies of the U.S. Government and certain users in countries
with high levels of concern over security, tend to select systems based largely
on detection capability.&#160; Many of the
Company&#146;s systems offer premium performance and have in some cases been priced
higher than many competing systems. The Company believes that its patented and
proprietary technology give it a strong competitive position in the sale of
security systems to customers concerned with performance and detection. The
Company also believes that its strategy </font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">6</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='6',FILE='C:\JMS\C900154\08-15969-1\task2985867\15969-1-ba-01.htm',USER='c900154',CD='Jun 13 09:44 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">of concentrating on products with unique features,
including Z Backscatter and Shaped Energy, and/or competitive pricing will give
it a strong position to increase its sales of X-ray systems. However, a number
of companies have developed products that compete with the Company&#146;s X-ray
inspection products. (See &#147;Forward-Looking Information and Factors Affecting
Future Performance&#148;)</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">ISO 9001
Certification</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In August&nbsp;2006, the
Company&#146;s Quality Management System was recertified under the ISO 9001:2000
Standard of the International Organization for Standardization which it has
been registered under since 2003.&#160; ISO
9001 is an internationally recognized quality management and assurance
standard.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In qualifying, the
Company met or exceeded the standards for establishing a quality management
system for preventing non-conformity at every level of the product life cycle,
from customer order, through development and production, to installation and
support.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company believes that
demonstrating continuous quality improvement is vital for building customer
satisfaction and making business processes more efficient in order to increase
its competitive edge.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Component
Availability</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Critical material and
subsystems are procured from both domestic suppliers as well as internationally
from global supply partners.&#160; These
supply sources are in some cases single sources of supply and the material provided
can have extended lead times.&#160; In
response to expanding customer demand in the global security screening market,
the Company has taken steps to mitigate sourcing risks by working closely with
its suppliers to ensure future material and subsystem availability to support
its production plans. In some cases, the Company has chosen to stock reserve
material to ensure future availability. Efforts have also included identifying
and qualifying second source suppliers for critical material and a number of
key subsystems in support of its product lines. The Company does not expect to
experience sustained difficulties in securing required material and subsystems
to support its forward business operations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Regulatory
Compliance</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">AS&amp;E</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">complies</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">with</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">applicable</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">federal</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">regulations</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">under</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Title</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">21</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;
">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">CFR</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Subchapter</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">J</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">-</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Radiological</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Health.</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">&#160; </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">All</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">AS&amp;E</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">cabinet</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">X-ray</font><font size="2" style

e</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">standards</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">including</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">21</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">CFR</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">1020.40.</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">All</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">personnel</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">inspection</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">systems</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="f
ont-size:10.0pt;">of</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">AS&amp;E</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">comply</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">with</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">voluntary</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">consensus</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">radiation</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">safety</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">standards</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><
font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">adopted</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">by</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">American</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">National</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Standards</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Institute</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ANSI</font><font size="2" style="font-size:11.0pt;">  </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">N43.17-2002.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Research
and Development</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company spent
approximately $12,306,000 of its own funds for research and development during
fiscal 2008, compared to $7,184,000 and $9,601,000 in fiscal 2007 and 2006,
respectively. The fiscal 2008 research and development efforts were focused on
design modifications and enhancements to existing products, the development of
new applications and the development of new products.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition, the Company
conducted government-sponsored research primarily focused on advances in X-ray
systems, image analysis and integrated system development for niche security
inspection problems. The Company recognized revenues of $13,978,000,
$6,597,000, and $2,804,000 in fiscal 2008, 2007, and 2006, respectively for
these efforts. Many of the Company&#146;s government sponsored research and
development contracts provide for a fixed fee or a reimbursement of allowable
costs plus a fixed fee. The Company&#146;s contracts in these areas are obtained by
submitting research and development proposals to various organizations,
sometimes in response to requests for such proposals.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Personnel</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of March&nbsp;31, 2008
the Company had 346 employees as compared to 299 employees at March&nbsp;31,
2007.&#160;&#160; It is the Company&#146;s policy to
have employees sign nondisclosure agreements as a condition of employment. None
of the Company&#146;s employees are represented by labor unions.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Sales
Backlog</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s firm
(signed contracts) sales backlog was $99,606,000, $105,634,000, and $68,840,000
at March&nbsp;31, 2008, March&nbsp;31, 2007, and March&nbsp;31, 2006,
respectively.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">7</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='7',FILE='C:\JMS\C900154\08-15969-1\task2985867\15969-1-ba-01.htm',USER='c900154',CD='Jun 13 09:44 2008' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Certain of the Company&#146;s
contracts with the U.S. Government contain clauses permitting the government to
terminate the contract for convenience upon certain terms and conditions,
including partial payment to the Company for work performed. Total contracts
with U.S Government agencies and subcontractors in the backlog were
$42,640,000, $58,833,000, and $30,058,000, at March&nbsp;31, 2008, 2007 and
2006, respectively. It is estimated that approximately 77% of the 2008 backlog
will be filled within the fiscal year ending March&nbsp;31, 2009.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Financial
Information about Foreign and Domestic Operations and Export Sales</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Most export sales are
transacted in U.S. dollars, and most are either secured by irrevocable letters
of credit or paid in advance. The following table shows the breakdown of net
sales and contract revenues to international and domestic customers and the
major regions of international activity based upon customer&#146;s country of
domicile. All assets are maintained within the United States with the exception
of inventory depots, inventory in transit or awaiting installation and cash
accounts maintained at foreign locations (approximately 4% of the Company&#146;s
assets).</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.2in;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Net
Sales and Contract Revenues</font></i></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="93%" style="border-collapse:collapse;width:93.32%;">
 <tr>

  </td>
  <td width="3%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:3.2%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="8%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:8.58%;">
  <p align="right" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">11</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="3%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:3.2%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">%</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:4.32%;">
  <p align="right" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:1.0%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="41%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:41.78%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">All Other</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="3%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:3.2%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="8%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:8.54%;">
  <p align="right" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="3%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:3.2%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">%</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:4.0%;">
  <p align="right" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="3%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:3.2%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="8%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:8.58%;">
  <p align="right" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#151;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="3%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:3.2%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">%</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:4.0%;">
  <p align="right" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  <td width="3%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:3.2%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  <td width="3%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:3.2%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">%</font></p>

  <td width="4%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:4.32%;">
  <p align="right" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:1.0%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
